If this patient is getting this colonoscopy for preventative screening, tell them you're glad they're taking this step to take care of their health.

 Nurse: Hi, this is Rachel calling from O'Connor Hospital. I'm an AI on a recorded line. Is this Eredira Amador?

 Nurse: Thank you. I'm calling about your upcoming colonoscopy on August 17 at 11:00 AM. Is this a good time to talk? 

 Patient: Yes. 

 Nurse: Great, thank you for your time. How has your day been so far? 

 Patient: It's been a difficult day. 

 Nurse: I'm sorry to hear that. If you feel comfortable, would you like to share what's been challenging today? 

 Patient: Channels today. 

 Nurse: I'm sorry to hear that you're having a tough day. 

 Patient: That's all. 

 Nurse: I'm sorry to hear that you're having a tough day. I hope things get better soon. As we move forward, I want to know how you're feeling about your upcoming colonoscopy procedure. Are there any concerns or questions you have? 

 Patient: Well, I just wanna make sure I'm gonna be okay. 

 Nurse: Absolutely, your safety and comfort are our top priorities. Your gastroenterologist, Doctor Meredith Bailey, is highly experienced and has performed over 1500 colonoscopies. She's dedicated to ensuring your procedure goes smoothly. Do you have any specific questions or concerns you'd like to discuss before we proceed? 

 Patient: No. Not at the moment. 

 Nurse: Alright. Please remember that you can ask me questions at any time during our conversation. I see on your chart that you're getting this colonoscopy due to blood in your stool. I acknowledge that it can be quite a process to go through this procedure. How are you feeling about it? 

 Patient: To know. 

 Nurse: I'm sorry, I didn't quite catch that. 

 Patient: Little nervous.
